title-group.article-title: Repair of degloving fingers with abdominal tunnelization flap

contrib-group.aff: Department of Plastic Surgery, University Clinical Centre of Kosovo, Pristina, Kosovo Email: zbuja70@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

body.p: Degloving injuries of the hand and fingers is one of the most severe and debilitating hand injuries and one of the most difficult management problems in hand surgery (Nazerani et al., 2011). Reconstruction of degloving injuries should be achieved with thin, pliable and sensitive skin that prevents contracture and stiffness, allowing rapid healing, early mobilization and to be cosmetically acceptable (Krishnamoorthy et al., 2011). The only procedures that give good results are a combination of flaps, pedicled or free vascularized, and skin graft (Chang et al., 1987).

We report an abdominal wall tunnelization technique used successfully in the case of an 18-year-old boy, who suffered a degloving injury of the distal half of the dorsum of the hand without exposure of extensor tendons, and of fingers two to five of his dominant right hand with exposure of the tendons, neurovascular bundle and distal phalanges (Figure 1).

caption.p: The degloving injury of the hand and fingers: (a) the volar side of fingers, (b) the dorsal side of hand and fingers.

body.p: On the third day after injury, after excision of all necrotic tissue and removal of distal phalanx of fifth fingers, we covered the wounds with an abdominal flap and skin graft. The design of the abdominal flap (Figure 2(a)) reflects the dimension of the fingers. Four incisions, the width of the fingers, admits the fingers and the fingertips exit below this incisions, through four incisions each of 1 cm. The exposed dorsum of the hand covered with skin graft (Figure 2(a)).

caption.p: (a) The design of abdominal tunnelization flap, (b) entry of degloving fingers and longitudinal incisions between fingers delay procedure.

body.p: After three weeks we made five longitudinal incisions between the fingers as a delay procedure (Figure 2(b)). At five weeks and seven weeks we completed the release. The volar parts of fingers are covered with a full skin graft. The abdominal donor site skin was grafted. Seven months after separation of the hand from the abdomen, tenolysis of flexor tendons, followed with physiotherapy treatment was performed.

Six months later, we performed flap thinning, capsulothomy and the placement of Kirschner wires in proximal interphalangeal joints of the four fingers. After six weeks we removed the Kirschner wires. Extension of fingers was normal, range of flexion of metacarpo-phalangeal joints was 100°, and proximal interphalangeal joints was from 28° to 50° (Figure 3). Sensation was satisfactory, in the dorsum (skin of the abdominal flap) and on the palm (full skin graft) as evidenced by 2 mm of static two-point discrimination.

caption.p: The fingers after rehabilitation program showing the range of flexion.

body.p: Nazerani et al. (2011) reported the compartmented abdominal flap in six patients with degloving injury, with fair success. And we found this technique to give an acceptable outcome in this patient.
